intro: Potamogeton obtusifolius f. microcarpus, commonly known as the dwarf pondweed, is a submerged aquatic plant characterized by its small, oval leaves that are typically less than 1 cm in length. It is a morphological variant of the broader species Potamogeton obtusifolius, distinguished by its reduced fruit size and more compact growth habit. This plant thrives in shallow, nutrient-rich waters and is often found in lakes, ponds, and slow-moving rivers. Its leaves are usually arranged in whorls and are often covered with fine hairs, contributing to its distinctive appearance. The plant plays an important role in aquatic ecosystems by providing habitat and food for various aquatic organisms.
